title: Amazon To FCC : Our Starlink Rival Needs More Time To Deploy
description: The company won't reach the July deadline to launch half of the Leo constellation. But the filing says Amazon has 'more than 100 missions planned through Q1 2029.'
content:
[Skip to Main Content](https://www.pcmag.com/news/amazon-to-fcc-we-need-more-time-to-launch-our-starlink-rival?test_uuid=04IpBmWGZleS0I0J3epvMrC&test_variant=B#main "Skip to Main Content")

PCMag editors select and review products
[independently](https://www.pcmag.com/about/pcmagcom-mission-statement).
If you buy through affiliate links, we may earn commissions, which help support our
[testing](https://www.pcmag.com/about/how-we-test-everything-we-review).

![Amazon Leo](https://i.pcmag.com/imagery/articles/00rjMxHxZlP77cumShc1fUC-1.fit_lim.v1769818197.jpg)

(Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP via Getty Images)


Amazon is asking for an extension to deploy its Starlink competitor, [Leo](https://www.pcmag.com/news/project-kuiper-satellite-service-rebrands-as-amazon-project-leo?test_uuid=04IpBmWGZleS0I0J3epvMrC&test_variant=A), and admits it won’t hit a deadline to operate half of the satellite constellation by this July.

On Friday, the company filed the extension with the Federal Communications Commission, which [greenlit](https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/FCC-20-102A1.pdf "(Opens in a new tab)") the satellite internet system back in 2020. As a condition, Amazon was supposed to launch and operate half of the 3,200 satellite constellation by July 30th, 2026, otherwise it risked losing authorization to complete the network.

But according to the [filing](https://www.scribd.com/document/990070214/01-30-26-gen1-Milestone-Waiver-Request-Redacted-For-Public-Inspection "(Opens in a new tab)"), the company only expects to have about 700 satellites in orbit by the deadline —far short of the needed 1,600. As of today, the Leo constellation only spans 180 satellites.

![PCMag logo](https://www.pcmag.com/images/pcmag-simplified.png)
